options.label: A
options.text: A theorem that states that the sum of an infinite series is always equal to the sum of its partial sums

options.label: B
options.text: A theorem that states that a convergent series can be rearranged to have any sum

options.label: C
options.text: A theorem that states that a divergent series can be rearranged to have any sum

options.label: D
options.text: A theorem that states that the sum of an infinite series is always equal to the sum of its positive terms

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Convergent series have a negative sum, while divergent series have a positive sum

options.label: D

title: 10 dangerous fashion trends

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the pigment developed by Carl Wilhelm Scheele in 1775, which was highly toxic because it contained arsenic?
What was the name of the disease caused by mercury poisoning that led to extreme emotional states and physical effects like tremors and difficulty walking?
What was the name of the radioactive element discovered by Marie and Pierre Curie in 1910, which was used in radium makeup?
What was the name of the compound derived from a poisonous plant called Deadly Nightshade, which was used to dilate pupils for a striking look?
What was the name of the synthetic plastic made from cellulose nitrate, which was highly flammable and used in early accessories like buttons and jewelry?
What was the name of the disease caused by radium poisoning that led to anemia, "radium jaw," and bone cancers in factory workers?
What was the name of the process used to make felt hats, which involved washing the pelts in an orange solution containing mercury nitrate?
What was the name of the chemical compound used to make lead carbonate, a powdery white lead used in Venetian ceruse?

options.label: D
options.text: Lead Acetic Acid and Carbon Dioxide

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.text: It represents the speaker's acceptance of their fate.

options.label: A
options.text: To focus on the physical aspects of dying.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a sense of wonder and spirituality in the dying process.

options.label: C
options.text: To provide sustenance and comfort to the dying through the senses.

options.label: D
options.text: To make dying a more painful and difficult experience.

options.label: A
options.text: To focus on the physical aspects of dying.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a sense of wonder and spirituality in the dying process.

options.label: C
options.text: To make dying a more painful and difficult experience.

options.label: D
options.text: To make life and health and healthcare about making life more wonderful, rather than just less horrible.

options.label: A
options.text: To focus on the physical aspects of dying.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a sense of wonder and spirituality in the dying process.

options.label: C
options.text: To make dying a more painful and difficult experience.

options.label: D

options.label: C

title: Why do dogs have floppy ears?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why domesticated animals, such as dogs, have floppy ears compared to their wild counterparts?

options.label: A
options.text: They have more adrenaline, making them more alert to their surroundings.

options.label: B
options.text: They have fewer neural crest cells, leading to a reduction in adrenaline production.

options.label: C
options.text: They have a different diet, which affects the development of their ears.

options.label: D
options.text: They have a genetic mutations that cause their ears to be floppy.

multiple-choice.question: Who first noticed the pattern of domestication syndrome, which includes traits such as floppy ears and shorter snouts in domesticated animals?

options.label: C
options.text: A scientist who came after Darwin

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the special group of cells that scientists believe are responsible for the domestication syndrome?
What is the primary function of neural crest cells in the development of vertebrate embryos?

options.label: B
options.text: To form parts of the face

options.label: C
options.text: To control the color of skin and hair

options.label: D
options.text: To travel to every corner of the body and take on various jobs

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if an animal was born with fewer neural crest cells or those cells didn't work well?

options.label: A
options.text: It would be more aggressive and have more adrenaline.

options.label: B
options.text: It would be less freaked out by humans and have less adrenaline.

options.label: C
options.text: It would have a different diet.

multiple-choice.question: What is the likely explanation for how dogs first got floppy ears?

options.label: A
options.text: They were bred to have floppy ears by humans.

options.label: B
options.text: They were born with fewer neural crest cells, leading to a reduction in cartilage production.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the hypothesis that scientists have been throwing around to explain the domestication syndrome?
What is the primary reason why scientists are interested in the neural crest cell hypothesis?

options.label: A
options.text: It explains every bit of domestication syndrome.

options.label: B
options.text: It provides an excuse for scientists to spend more time with their pets.

options.label: C
options.text: It explains how domesticated animals became tamer.

options.label: D
options.text: It explains how wild animals became more aggressive.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the show that presented the information about the neural crest cell hypothesis?
What is the name of the scientist who discovered neural crest cells in the same year that Darwin published his book?

options.label: C
options.text: A scientist who came after Darwin

A community is considering implementing a recycling program to reduce its waste output. What are some potential benefits of this decision?
